summary.para: Starts calculating the value asynchronously, if this is the first time the value has been called for. Returns the task to be awaited.
On subsequent calls, returns the same task (either completed or not).

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.AsyncLazy`1.GetValueCold
member.summary: Cold-path for to initiate its calculation. Skipped on further calls.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.AsyncLazy`1.OnCustomGetValue
member.summary: Override in derived classes to avoid creating a ctor-passed lambda. Replaces the factory constructor parameter. This WILL NOT be called from the base ctor. This will be called: 1) Never, if the user never asks for the lazy task. 2) Once, the first time the user asks for the lazy task, if this method succeeds. 3) If this method throws, then each next time the user asks for the lazy task, until it succeeds.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.TypeHierarchyMap`1
member.summary:
Represents the dictionary of values accessed via keys. Allows using derived/implementing types as a keys for lookup by trying to find the "best" matching registration of given some instance.
There are disambiguation rules if key K matches both A and B key types, in a following order: * If type A is assignable from B, type B will be chosen as more specific; * Otherwise if there is no subtyping relationship between A and B, the type key registered first will be chosen.
Example: Given {IComparable,object} map, 'IComparable' will be chosen for 'int' key (first rule)

member.summary: Whether option is keyed or non-keyed. If keyed then Key, Shortcut and GetKeyDefinition must not return null or throw.

member.summary: Key name.

member.summary: 0-based index for non-keyed option.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Attributes.AbstractOptionAttribute.IsNonKeyedTail
member.summary: If set to true then all non-keyed arguments starting from NonKeyedIndex considered as multi value for this option.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Attributes.AbstractOptionAttribute.IsRequired
member.summary: Whether option is required or not.
member.remarks:
IMPORTANT! If IsRequired true then option MUST BE specified and is always ignored, but still usable.
For example, [StringOption("opt", IsRequired = true, EmptyValue = "awesome")] requires opt to be specified, but it can be specified with or without value: --opt /* will have "awesome" value */ or --opt == my-value.
IMPORTANT! IsRequired has additional meaning for ImplicitGroup-s: "option required to activate implicit group".
For example, [BoolOption(..., IsRequired = true)] outside implicit group is useless (because value always will be true), but inside implicit group it means 'if this option is specified then appropriate implicit group activated'.

member.summary: Formats option value to string presentation.
member.remarks:
If value is a single-value then single string is returned.
If value is a multi-value and Separator is defined for this option then single string of joined single-values is returned.
If Separator IS NOT defined then sequence of single-value strings is returned (necessary to support '--key=value1 --key=value2 ...' syntax).

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.ICommandLineBuilder`1
member.summary: Builds command line from typed options model.

members.member:
Maps CommandLineArgument-s to typed options model.
Features:
* supports types: string, int, bool, enum, TimeSpan, FileSystemPath
* extensible: easy to map custom types
* supports collection assignable from T[]
* supports multi-value specified via separator or repeating key (e.g. '--list=a,b,c' or '--list=a --list=b --list=c')
* supports commands (a-la 'git push')
* supports implicit group deduced on the set of provided arguments
* supports mutually exclusive groups and multi-groups
* provides auto-help generation
* supports sample generation from options model
* supports raw command line tail: useful for passing arguments to started child-process
See CommandLineMapperExamples in test-project.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.ICommandLineMapper`1.GetKeyDefinitions
member.summary: Returns KeyDefinition-s built by options model.
member.remarks:
Key definitions are used by parser to support feature 'space as value separator'.
E.g. -f <file-name>
If -f option expects a value then <file-name> is a value for keyed option 'f' otherwise <file-name> is a non-keyed option.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.AbstractParser
member.summary:
Basic implementation which able to parse the following cases:
<non-keyed-value>
<key-marker><key>
<key-marker><key>:<value>
<key-marker><key>=<value>
<key-marker><key> <value> // if 'space-as-value-separator' feature enabled
<shortcut-marker><shortcut>[<shortcut>...]
<shortcut-marker><shortcut>[<shortcut>...]:<value>
<shortcut-marker><shortcut>[<shortcut>...]=<value>
<shortcut-marker><shortcut>[<shortcut>...] <value> // if 'space-as-value-separator' feature enabled
<shortcut-marker><shortcut>[<shortcut>...]<value>
where <shortcut> is a single char
Also supports <non-keyed-mark> after wich all following arguments are treated as non-keyed.
See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Command-line_interface#Option_conventions_in_Unix-like_systems

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.AbstractParser.mySortedKeyMarks
member.summary: We have to sort all KeyMarks by their length so that if both '--' and '-' are present in KeyMarks and the command line fragment is '--foo' the TrimShortcutMark will return 'foo' rather than '-foo' if in KeyMarks the '-' mark is specified before '--' mark

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.BackwardCompatibilityParser
member.summary:
Treats - (single dash) as key marker but not a shortcut. Under Windows / (slash) also treated as key marker.
<key-marker> ::= -- | / | -
<shortcut-marker> ::= (none)
<non-keyed-mark> ::= --
Examples: --name=value --name:value /name=value /name:value -name=value -name:value -- -non-keyed --non-keyed

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.CompactHelpGenerator
member.summary: Generates help expanding groups inplace. Might be useful for tools with simple command line.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.DefaultHelpGenerator
member.summary: Default implementation of help generator.
member.example:
Usage: dotMem [--log-level[=ERROR|WARN|INFO]] [--log-file=<file-path>] [--save-to=<dir-path>] <command>
[--log-level[=ERROR|WARN|INFO]] logging level [--log-file=<file-path>] log file path [--save-to=<dir-path>] folder path to save workspace to
<command> help Display help related to specified command. get-snapshot Get snapshot of running .NET process. start Start standalone application under profiling and get snapshot by triggers.

get-snapshot Get snapshot of running .NET process. Usage: dotMem get-snapshot <process-spec> [--as-admin]
<process-spec> ::= <pid-spec> | <name-spec>
<pid-spec> ::= --pid|-i=<pid> Specify process by PID.
--pid|-i=<pid> process identifier
<name-spec> ::= --name|-n=<process-name> [--with-max-mem] [--all] Specify process by name with some optional conditions.
--name|-n=<process-name> process name with optional extension [--with-max-mem] snapshot a process with max memory consumption [--all] snapshot all processes with specified name
[--as-admin] elevate to admin privileges
E.g: dotMem get-snapshot --pid=2025 Get snapshot of process with PID 2025.
E.g: dotMem get-snapshot --name=PaintDotNet --all Get snapshot of all processes with name PaintDotNet.
E.g: dotMem get-snapshot --name=PaintDotNet --with-max-mem Get snapshot of process with name PaintDotNet, if several instances are running pick one which consumes max memory.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.DefaultHelpGenerator.DescriptionGenerator.DefineOptionMacros(JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Attributes.AbstractOptionAttribute)
member.summary:
The following macros defined for current option:
${Key} - without key marker; only defined if option keyed
${Shortcut} - without shortcut marker; only defined if option has shortcut
${Alias} - without marker; only defined if option has alias
${DefaultValue} - ; only defined if default value was specified
${EmptyValue} - ; only defined if default value was specified
${FormattedKey} - key and shortcut with appropriate markers, something like `--key|-k` ${sep} - ; only defined if separator was specified

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.Impl.DefaultHelpGenerator.DefineGlobalMacros(JetBrains.Util.CommandLineMapper.FormattedTextBuilder,System.Type)
member.summary:
${AppName} - application name
${AppNameDotExe} - application name with `.exe` suffix
${EnvTempDir} - temp path environment variable (%Temp% or $TMPDIR) depending on running platform
${ExitCode.Failure} - value of
${ExitCode.Success} - value of
${--} - key marker (`--` or `/`)
${-} - shortcut marker (`-`)
${=} - value separator (`=` or `:`)
${/} - path separator (`/` or `\`) depending on running platform
${Help} - name of help command or formatted help key

member.summary: Allocates an MMF the standard way, just as this object would do by default.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.OpenFullStream(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime)
member.summary: Opens a view on the whole stream which can change the length freely to grow or shring. There might be at most one such view. No other substreams are allowed: no tail-growing substreams (because this one is essentialyl tail-growing as well); no immutable substreams (obviously); no fixed-length substreams (because this stream might shring past them, and when created, it resets committed length to zero, so no other streams might exist).

summary.para: Opens an immutable stream without a lifetime. Effectively, the lifetime of the class still limits the usable lifetime of the stream, so you have to make sure all active uses fall within. Other than that, the stream is “closed” as soon as it's garbage collected.
Stream instances are not reused because they have to have independent positioning, but they reuse some of the data to make sure digest is not calculated anew for each clone.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.OpenImmutableSubstreamWithLifetime(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.UInt64,System.UInt64)
member.summary: Opens an immutable stream which looks on a view within the body of this stream. The stream is considered closed when its lifetime ends. Each call opens a new stream with its own lifetime.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.OpenSubstreamFixedLength(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,System.UInt64,System.UInt64,JetBrains.Util.Storage.StructuredStorage.StreamOpenFlags.ReadWrite)
member.summary: Opens a stream which looks on a view within the body of this stream. Cannot change its length. Writable and readonly streams must not intersect.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.OpenSubstreamForAppending(JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime)
member.summary: Opens an initially empty stream which writes to the end of this stream. Can grow both its length and the parent stream length. Can't have more than one such. Always RW.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.ReadAt(System.UInt64,System.Void*,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the current memory stream holder without allocating a substream — same as opening a fixed-length readonly substream for the range and reading, but skips the checks and creation. Cannot read from within the current appending stream, only part is available. If is active, then no memory is available for reads here.
member.param: The stream offset to start reading at.
Points to the first byte of the destination buffer.
The number of bytes to copy.
member.remarks: There's no WriteAt because it'd still have to do all the slow checks on if there're any conflicting immutable streams, so create a substream for that.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.ReleaseBanks
member.summary: You can call this if you're not going to be using this object for some time. They'll be reopened automatically.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.BankSwitchingMemoryStreamSimple.Bank.RefCount
member.summary: Incremented (thread-safely) for the time smb is using the bank for operations. Prevents releasing the bank view. Zero means the bank is not in use, available for use, and can be freed. A very negavtive value (like, MinValue) is set atomically before releasing the bank, to make sure noone locks it for use. Upon creation, the bank gets a valid view and a ref count of 1, assuming the bank is initially in use and shan't be freed, don't forget to decrease.

member.summary: Releases and NULLs the view, unless in use.
member.returns: True if released now. A released bank always returns True.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.SimpleTrie`2.KeyEnumerator`2

summary.para: A non-allocating compound key producer function, as an alternative to passing the of keys as the compound key.
Defines the path in the trie.
To produce the keys in the path, an algorithm will call repeatedly.

member.param: The static context. This is passed thru as is from algorithm user to the algorithm and by the algorithm to the key enumerator function. Not supposed to change with iteration, though it's up to key enumerator implemenation. Example: the string on which to enumerate parts.

The state of the enumerator. Passed by reference. On the first call, would be NULL. On each call the key enumerator implementation is expected to change this state so that on the next call it returned the next part.
The next key, if return value is True. Undefined otherwise.
member.returns: Whether this iteration produced a valid item. True means is the next valid key. False means the iteration has gone out of bounds and is over, is an undefined value, iteration should now stop.
member.remarks: The iteration is not guaranteed to be completed by the caller (might abort after few first items). There is no “enumeration dispose” call.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.SubStream
member.summary: Sometimes we have to trick some feature into thinking that it works on its own stream, while actually it gets only a substream from some other larger stream (or file). An example would be features like ZIP which would seek into beginning and the end. Another case is appending to a larger stream, while some features would like to rewind first. And it also won't dispose the underlying stream on close.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.DataStructures.ChunkPackedIntArray
member.summary:
Presents uint[] (this) packed into uint[][] (myChunks). Each chunk is UncheckedPackedIntArray which supplies compression. Chunks are used to avoid LOH.
To take i-th element of 'this', invoke GetItem(i, valueBits, 0). You can also use this[ith] to get/set values with array of one element (in case of valueBits less than '32'.
One can increase or reduce size of elem by invocation of IncreaseValueBits(ChunkPackedIntArray oldArray, int newValueBits)

member.summary: Returns the first element of array

member.summary: Adds an item into the collection if it does not exist
member.param: Item to add
member.returns: true if item added, false if it existed previously

The length of the one chunk. Must be pow of 2

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.DataStructures.UncheckedPackedIntArray
member.summary:
Presents uint[] (this) packed into another uint[] (myData). valueBits parameter for each method denotes size in bits of one element of 'this' Can be much or less than '32' bits, which is the size of myData element. No range checks are performed.
To take i-th element of 'this', invoke GetItem(i, valueBits, 0). You can also use this[ith] to get/set values with array of one element (in case of valueBits less than '32'.
One can increase or reduce size of elem by invocation of IncreaseValueBits(UncheckedPackedIntArray oldArray, int length, int oldValueBits, int newValueBits)

member.summary: Calculates this[iSubItem]

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException
member.summary: Represents the exception that occurs when a fails.

remarks.para: The exception that occurs when a DNS request fails at any level.

This class is used to represent two broad types of exceptions:
Win32 API Exceptions that occurred when calling the DnsQuery API
Exceptions of other types that occurred when working with the and classes.
Win32 errors that are DNS specific are specified in the enumeration but if the returned is not defined in that enum then the number returned will be defined in WinError.h.
Exceptions of other types are available through the InnerException property.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of
member.remarks: Used to raise a with all the default properties. The message property will return: Unspecified DNS exception.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of
member.param: the human readable description of the problem
member.remarks: Used to raise a where the only important information is a description about the error. The property will return 0 or SUCCESS indicating that the DNS API calls succeeded, regardless of whether they did or did not.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException.#ctor(System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of
member.param: the human readable description of the problem
the error code () if the DnsQuery api failed
member.remarks: Used to raise a where the underlying DNS API call fails. In this case, the property is the most important information about the exception. In most cases, the number returned is a value in the enum however, if it is not, the error is defined in WinError.h.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException.ErrorCode
member.summary: Gets the error code () if the DnsQuery api failed. Will be set to success (0) if the API didn't fail but another part of the code did.
member.remarks: Win32 errors that are DNS specific are specified in the enumeration but if the returned is not defined in that enum then the number returned will be defined in WinError.h.
member.value: Value will be defined in WinError.h if not defined in the enum.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of
member.param: the human readable description of the problem
the exception that caused the underlying error
member.remarks: Used to raise a where the exception is some other type but a typeof(DnsException) is desired to be raised instead. In this case, the property always returns 0 or SUCCESS and is a useless property.

member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type.

A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the comparands. The return value has these meanings:
Value Meaning
Less than zero This instance is less than obj. The types do not match.
Zero This instance is equal to obj.
Greater than zero This instance is greater than obj. The do not match.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest
member.summary: Represents one DNS request. Allows for a complete DNS record lookup on a given domain using the Windows API.

remarks.para: The DnsRequest class represents a complete DNS request for a given domain on a specified DNS server, including all options. The DnsRequest class uses the Windows API to do the query and the dlls used are only found on Windows 2000 or higher machines. The class will throw a exception if run on an machine not capable of using the APIs that are required.
Version Information
Created by: Bill Gearhart. Based on code by Patrik Lundin. See version 1.0 remarks below. Specific attention was given to the exposed interface which got a 110% overhaul.

Notable changes from the previous version:
structs filled with constants were changed to enums
.net datatypes were changed to c# datatypes
every object is now in it's own *.cs file
custom collections and exceptions added
better object orientation - request and response classes created for the dns query request/response session so that it follows the .NET model
eliminated duplicate recs returned by an ALL query
bad api return code enumeration added
ToString() overridden to provide meaningful info for many of the dns data structs
documentation and notes were created for all classes
added check to ensure code only runs on w2k or better
obsolete DNS record types are now marked as such
newer enum values added to DnsQueryType enum
compiled html documentation was written which always takes 20 times longer than writing the code does.
this list of changes was compiled by your's truly...
smoothed out object and member names so they were more intuitive - for instance: DNS_MX_DATA became MXRecord
added call to DnsRecordListFree API to free resources after DnsQuery call
altered DnsQuery API call to allow for servers other than the local DNS server from being queried
Created by: Patrik Lundin

Based on code found at: http://www.c-sharpcorner.com/Code/2002/April/DnsResolver.asp
Initial implementation.

member.summary: http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/en-us/dns/dns/dnsquery.asp

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.Servers
member.summary: Gets a collection of DNS servers to use for the current request. If the collection contains no items, the local DNS servers are used.
member.remarks: If the collection contains 0 references, the default DNS servers are used. Otherwise, servers are used in a decending order from their ordinal position in the collection. You can add as many DNS Servers as you need to the collection by host name or IP address.
member.value: A that can be used to manage the DNS servers that will be used for the query.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.UseTCPOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to use TCP only for the query.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to use TCP instead of UDP for the query
member.remarks: If set to true, the DNS query will be done via TCP rather than UDP. This is useful if the DNS service you are trying to reach is running on TCP but not on UDP.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.AcceptTruncatedResponse
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to accept truncated results — does not retry under TCP.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to accept truncated results.
member.remarks: Determines wherher or not the server will be re-queried in the event that a response was truncated.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.NoRecursion
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to perform an iterative query
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to use recursion to resolve the query.
member.remarks: Specifically directs the DNS server not to perform recursive resolution to resolve the query.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.BypassCache
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to bypass the resolver cache on the lookup. This must be set to true if you specified a server in the collection.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to bypass the cache and use the list of servers in the collection.
member.remarks: Setting this to true allows you to specify one or more DNS servers to query instead of querying the local DNS cache and server. If false is set, the list of servers is ignored and the local DNS cache and server is used to resolve the query.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.QueryCacheOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to direct DNS to perform a query on the local cache only
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to only use the DNS cache to resolve a query.
member.remarks: This option allows you to query the local DNS cache only instead of making a DNS request over either UDP or TCP. This property represents the logical opposite of the property.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.WireOnly
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to direct DNS to perform a query using the network only, bypassing local information.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to use the network only instead of local information.
member.remarks: This property represents the logical opposite of the property.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.NoLocalName
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to direct DNS to ignore the local name.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to ignore the local name.
member.remarks: Determines how the DNS query handles local names.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.NoHostsFile
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to prevent the DNS query from consulting the HOSTS file.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to deny access to the HOSTS file when querying.
member.remarks: Determines how the DNS query handles accessing the HOSTS file when querying for DNS information.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.NoNetbt
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to prevent the DNS query from using NetBT for resolution.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to deny access to NetBT during the query.
member.remarks: Determines how the DNS query handles accessing NetBT when querying for DNS information.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.QueryReturnMessage
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to direct DNS to return the entire DNS response message.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to return the entire response.
member.remarks: Determines how the DNS query expects the response to be received from the server.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.DnsRequest.TreatAsFQDN
member.summary: Gets or sets whether or not to prevent the DNS response from attaching suffixes to the submitted name in a name resolution process.
member.value: Boolean indicating whether or not to allow suffix attachment during resolution.
member.remarks: Determines how the DNS server handles suffix appending to the submitted name during name resolution.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord
member.summary: Represents a DNS Location record (DNS_LOC_DATA)

remarks.para: The LOCRecord structure is used in conjunction with the and classes to programmatically manage DNS entries.

For , altitude above or below sea level may be used as an approximation of altitude relative to the [WGS 84] spheroid, however, there will be differences due to the Earth's surface not being a perfect spheroid. For example, the geoid (which sea level approximates) for the continental US ranges from 10 meters to 50 meters below the [WGS 84] spheroid. Adjustments to and/or will be necessary in most cases. The Defense Mapping Agency publishes geoid height values relative to the [WGS 84] ellipsoid.
For more information about the LOC RR, see RFC 1876.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.Version
member.summary: Gets or sets the version
member.remarks: Version number of the representation. Must be zero.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.Size
member.summary: Gets or sets the size
member.remarks: Diameter of a sphere enclosing the described entity, in centimeters, expressed as a pair of four-bit unsigned integers, each ranging from zero to nine, with the most significant four bits representing the base and the second number representing the power of ten by which to multiply the base. This format allows sizes from 0e0 (<1cm) to 9e9 (90,000km) to be expressed.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.HorPrec
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal precision
member.remarks: Horizontal precision of the data, in centimeters, expressed using the same representation as wSize. This is the diameter of the horizontal circle of error, rather than a plus or minus value. Matches the interpretation of wSize; to get a plus or minus value, divide by 2.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.VerPrec
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical precision
member.remarks: Vertical precision of the data, in centimeters, expressed using the same representation as wSize. This value represents the total potential vertical error, rather than a plus or minus value. Matches the interpretation of wSize; to get a plus or minus value, divide by 2. If altitude above or below sea level is used as an approximation for altitude relative to the [WGS 84] ellipsoid, the precision value should be adjusted.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.Latitude
member.summary: Gets or sets the latitude of the location
member.remarks: Latitude of the center of the sphere described by wSize, expressed as a 32-bit integer, with the most significant octet first (network standard byte order), in thousandths of a second of arc. 2^31 represents the equator, larger numbers are north latitude.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.Longitude
member.summary: Gets or sets the longitude of the location
member.remarks: Longitude of the center of the sphere described by wSize, expressed as a 32-bit integer, most significant octet first (network standard byte order), in thousandths of a second of arc, rounded away from the prime meridian. 2^31 represents the prime meridian, larger numbers are east longitude..

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.DnsAPI.LOCRecord.Altitude
member.summary: Gets or sets the altitude of the location
member.remarks: Altitude of the center of the sphere described by wSize, expressed as a 32-bit integer, most significant octet first (network standard byte order), in centimeters, from a base of 100,000m below the [WGS 84] reference spheroid used by GPS (semimajor axis a=6378137.0, reciprocal flattening rf=298.257223563). See Remarks for more information.

4 Elliptic curve cryptography

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Dotnet.TargetFrameworkIds.TargetFrameworkId

Docs: https://docs.nuget.org/create/targetframeworks (general) https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/Documentation/architecture/net-platform-standard.md (portable profiles) https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/articles/standard/library RSRP-459103 contains quite a few links and comments about it Xamarin/ Android: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/schema/target-frameworks netstandard: https://github.com/dotnet/standard/blob/master/docs/versions.md

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Extension.AppDomainEx.InvokeCtorInAppdomain``1(System.AppDomain,System.Linq.Expressions.Expression{System.Func{``0}})
member.summary: Calls the given ctor expression in the target appdomain, sending the given arguments. The argument instances cross the domain boundary according to their serialization/marshalling, safe if all of mscorlib types. If not for the reference you have to use in the Expression, it would have been fully isolated, meaning the same assembly does not have to be loaded into both. With an expression, obviously you need the type, but if you supply another path, it might be two different versions. If you take the code inside and call it manualy on strings and args without the help of the expression, then it would be fully isolated. Calling ctor is the only option to do so — managed APIs do not allow to call static methods without cross-loading assemblies in both appdomains, just ctors. Unfortunately, a ctor cannot return anything, assuming we cannot unwrap the object itself (and load its assembly): it ain't got any return value, and any ref/out parameters are NOT marshalled back.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Extension.AppDomainEx.WithTemporaryAppDomain(System.String,System.Action{System.AppDomain},System.AppDomainSetup,System.Security.Policy.Evidence)
member.summary: Creates an application domain, executes the action, destroys the appdomain.
member.param: Base name for the appdomain, an unique suffix would be added.
Runs arbitrary code with the new appdomain. Appdomain is destoryed when the function completes.
Params.
Params.

members.member: Converts value string to it Windows representation. as a byte-encoded string. Encoding algorithm adds "/" character to capital letters, i.e. "A" is encoded as "/A". Character '\' is encoded as '//', '/' is encoded as '\'. Then encoding scheme similar to jdk's native2ascii converter is used to convert java string to a byte array of ASCII characters.
Converts value string from its Windows representation to java string. See {@link #toWindowsValueString(String) toWindowsValueString()} for the description of the encoding algorithm.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Extension.ZipEntryEx.AsFileItem(ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipFile)
member.summary: Represents a ZIP file entry as an immutable file item. You MUST NOT use the returned stream beyond the lifetime (pass it as the to ensure). When used in the build system, this usually means opening zip files eternally (by GC). If the ZIP entry is not compressed, it's a direct view over the parent stream of the ZIP. Make sure it's immutable as well. If the entry is compressed, then it's lazy-decompressed up to the requested bytes. Beware that if the entry is also a nested ZIP file, then opening it would require reading the end of the file, for the dictionary.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Extension.ZipEntryEx.GetImmutableStream(ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipFile)
member.summary: For a ZIP file entry, gets an immutable clonable stream over its body. You MUST NOT use the returned stream beyond the lifetime. When used in the build system, this usually means opening zip files eternally (by GC). If the ZIP entry is not compressed, it's a direct view over the parent stream of the ZIP. Make sure it's immutable as well. If the entry is compressed, then it's lazy-decompressed up to the requested bytes. Beware that if the entry is also a nested ZIP file, then opening it would require reading the end of the file, for the dictionary.

summary.para: Allows to pass a return value thru a void-result .
Suppose the following piece of code that should be surrounded with some pre- and post-activity:
If the activity is available as an , the code is surrounded with using without any problem with return statement:
Suppose that the surrounding activity is implemented as a function that takes an to execute in the scope (e.g. ):
This won't compile, because ExecuteInScope is void and the action that it takes to execute is also void.
A temp local variable could be an option to use it for assignment, but it's hard to maintain in case the inner action has multiple returns against various code paths.
This function wraps the ExecuteInScope call and gives you a functor that turns your int-returning inner code into a void action suitable for the executor:

We will use ',' as the list separator, unless it's the same as the decimal separator. If it *is*, then we can't determine if, say, "23,5" is one number or two. member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Interop.ImportAddressTableHook.Install(System.String,System.String,System.Void*,System.Delegate)
member.summary: Installs an Import Address Table (IAT) hook. You choose a function (, ) whose entry will be replaced in the IAT of the specified module () to point to your own implementation () instead.
member.param: Name of the module in which the function-to-be-hooked is defined. Example: USER32.DLL.

Name of the function to be hooked. Example: SystemParametersInfoW. Note that for the functions that have separate ANSI and Wide versions you must include a suffix in the function name. Must have the stdcall (WINAPI, PASCAL) calling convention.
The module whose IAT is to be patched. Its calls to the Function will be intercepted.

The new implementation to replace the Function, in view of . The hook will hold a reference on the delegate. Note that it's up to you to provide the appropriate signature of the delegate, which must match the one of the Function. Pay attention to the charset and bitness issues.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Interop.ImportAddressTableHook.Install(System.String,System.String,System.String,System.Delegate)

member.param: Name of the module in which the function-to-be-hooked is defined. Example: USER32.DLL.

Name of the function to be hooked. Example: SystemParametersInfoW. Note that for the functions that have separate ANSI and Wide versions you must include a suffix in the function name. Must have the stdcall (WINAPI, PASCAL) calling convention.
The module whose IAT is to be patched. Its calls to the Function will be intercepted. Must be loadable with LoadLibrary (or already loaded).

The new implementation to replace the Function, in view of . The hook will hold a reference on the delegate. Note that it's up to you to provide the appropriate signature of the delegate, which must match the one of the Function. Pay attention to the charset and bitness issues.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Logging.LoggingHelpers.WithLoggingProgressMessagesAsync``1(JetBrains.Lifetimes.OuterLifetime,System.String,JetBrains.Application.Threading.Tasks.ITaskHost,JetBrains.Util.ILogger,System.Func{System.Threading.Tasks.Task{``0}},System.Func{System.String})
member.summary: Starts logging progress messages with level periodically if the activity wrapped with this method takes long enough, and issues a final message with total time only if any intermediate messages were written.

Starts logging progress messages with the given logging level periodically if the activity wrapped with this method takes long enough, and issues a final message with total time only if any intermediate messages were written.
member.param: Limiting lifetime of the activity.

Display name for the activity, would be included within progress messages. Either all-lowercase, or All Title Case recommended, no punctuation at the end. Examples: "Download Packages", "source code compilation".
The async payload. Progress messages will be issued while this function is executed or its task is awaited.
Optional. An extra suffix sentence for the periodical progress message, would be calculated each time we're about to report it. Might write the number of downloaded bytes and such.
Optional. Timeout before issuing the first progress message. If the activity is faster than this, no messages would be issued at all. by default.
Optional. Interval between next progress messages. by default.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.ColorManagement.RGBtoHLS(System.UInt32,System.Byte@,System.Byte@,System.Byte@)
member.summary:
RGBtoHLS() takes a DWORD RGB value and translates it to HLS BYTEs.
A point of reference for the algorithms is Foley and Van Dam, "Fundamentals of Interactive Computer Graphics," Pages 618-19. Their algorithm is in floating point. CHART implements a less general (hardwired ranges) integral algorithm.
There are potential round-off errors throughout this sample. ((0.5 + x)/y) without floating point is phrased ((x + (y/2))/y), yielding a very small round-off error. This makes many of the following divisions look strange.
member.param: The source RGB color.
Resulting Hue value.
Resulting Luminance value.
Resulting Saturation value.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.HumanPerceptibleColor
member.summary: Color representation with specific to be accurate to human perception of parameters like saturation, brightness. This model is similar to HSB except to taking account different degrees to which each of the primary (RGB) colors affects human perception of the overall brightness of a color

member.summary: Gets or set saturation (in range [0...1])

member.summary: Gets or set brightness as it is perceived by human (in range [0...1])

summary.para: 32bpp with alpha, alpha not premultiplied.
Binary format: BB GG RR AA or 0xAARRGGBB, no alpha premultiplication (“unassociated alpha” format).

member.summary: Hex in RRGGBBAA / RRGGBB / RGBA / RGB / #RRGGBBAA / #RRGGBB / #RGBA / #RGB format.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRgbaColor.From_BB_GG_RR_AA(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Conversion for the raw binary form where blue goes first (in the lowest bits, as we got low endianness), then green, red, and alpha is in the highest bits: BB GG RR AA. The hexadecimal notation for this layout would be 0xAARRGGBB with highest bits written first. This is the natural memory layout for this color object. Doing an explicit cast operator or reinterpret-cast will yield the same result.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRgbaColor.From_BB_GG_RR(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Conversion for the raw binary form where blue goes first (in the lowest bits, as we got low endianness), then green, red, and the highest bits which normally define alpha are ignored and substituted for FF: BB GG RR FF. The hexadecimal notation for this layout would be 0xFFRRGGBB with highest bits written first. This is the natural memory layout for this color object. Doing an explicit cast operator or reinterpret-cast will yield the same result.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRgbaColor.To_BB_GG_RR_AA
member.summary: Conversion for the raw binary form where blue goes first (in the lowest bits, as we got low endianness), then green, red, and alpha is in the highest bits: BB GG RR AA. The hexadecimal notation for this layout would be 0xAARRGGBB with highest bits written first. This is the natural memory layout for this color object. Doing an explicit cast operator or reinterpret-cast will yield the same result.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetSystemColors
member.summary: A runtime-agnostic table of “system” color constants. This currently only has direct meaning on Windows NT. For correct use on any system, incl remote usage within backend, use the Theming subsystem.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetSystemColors.SystemColorCode
member.summary: Important! Matches numerically WinForms colors. Until we add our own impl for retrieving system colors, these must be binary compatible.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.SystemColorsWin
member.summary: Delegates to WinForms for now. We probably should have a native impl for Windows when we start splitting, with default colors fallback for other environments.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetMatrix.MultiplyMatrix(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetMatrix@,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetMatrix@)
member.summary: Multiplies two transformations, where the behavior is matrix1 *= matrix2. This code exists so that we can efficient combine matrices without copying the data around, since each matrix is 52 bytes. To reduce duplication and to ensure consistent behavior, this is the method which is used to implement Matrix * Matrix as well.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect
member.summary: A 2D rectangle in physical (device-specific, hence depending on the resolution of that device, such as display screen) coordinates. Rects are stored as X, Y (Location) and Width and Height (JetPhysicalSize). As a result, Rects cannot have negative Width or Height. Forked from System.Windows.Rect.

member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to the values of the parameters

member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to the values of the parameters. Width and Height must be non-negative

member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to bound the two points provided.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.#ctor(System.Reflection.Missing)
member.summary: A special empty rect ctor to bypass checks.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Bottom
member.summary: Bottom Property - This is a read-only alias for Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.BottomLeft
member.summary: BottomLeft Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPhysicalPoint which is at X, Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity, negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.BottomRight
member.summary: BottomRight Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPhysicalPoint which is at X + Width, Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity, negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Empty
member.summary: Empty - a static property which provides an Empty rectangle. X and Y are positive-infinity and Width and Height are negative infinity. This is the only situation where Width or Height can be negative.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Height
member.summary: Height - The Height component of the JetPhysicalSize. This cannot be set to negative, and will only be negative if this is the empty rectangle, in which case it will be negative infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.IsEmpty
member.summary: IsEmpty - this returns true if this rect is the Empty rectangle. Note: If width or height are 0 this Rectangle still contains a 0 or 1 dimensional set of points, so this method should not be used to check for 0 area.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Left
member.summary: Left Property - This is a read-only alias for X If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Location
member.summary: Location - The JetPhysicalPoint representing the origin of the Rectangle

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Right
member.summary: Right Property - This is a read-only alias for X + Width If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Size
member.summary: JetPhysicalSize - The JetPhysicalSize representing the area of the Rectangle

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Top
member.summary: Top Property - This is a read-only alias for Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.TopLeft
member.summary: TopLeft Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPhysicalPoint which is at X, Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity, positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.TopRight
member.summary: TopRight Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPhysicalPoint which is at X + Width, Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity, positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Width
member.summary: Width - The Width component of the JetPhysicalSize. This cannot be set to negative, and will only be negative if this is the empty rectangle, in which case it will be negative infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.X
member.summary: X - The X coordinate of the Location. If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalRect.Y
member.summary: Y - The Y coordinate of the Location If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPhysicalThickness
member.summary: A 2D thickness/padding in physical (device-specific, hence depending on the resolution of that device, such as display screen) coordinates. JetPhysicalThickness is a value type used to describe the thickness of frame around a rectangle. It contains four ints each corresponding to a side: Left, Top, Right, Bottom. Forked from System.Windows.Thickness.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect
member.summary: A 2D rectangle in logical (device-independent and resolution-independent) coordinates. Rects are stored as X, Y (Location) and Width and Height (JetSize). As a result, Rects cannot have negative Width or Height. Forked from System.Windows.Rect.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPoint,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetSize)
member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to the values of the parameters

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to the values of the parameters. Width and Height must be non-negative

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPoint,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPoint)
member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to bound the two points provided.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetPoint,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetVector)
member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to bound the point provided and the point which results from point + vector.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetSize)
member.summary: Constructor which sets the initial values to bound the (0,0) point and the point that results from (0,0) + size.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.#ctor(System.Reflection.Missing)
member.summary: A special empty rect ctor to bypass checks.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Bottom
member.summary: Bottom Property - This is a read-only alias for Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.BottomLeft
member.summary: BottomLeft Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPoint which is at X, Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity, negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.BottomRight
member.summary: BottomRight Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPoint which is at X + Width, Y + Height If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity, negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Empty
member.summary: Empty - a static property which provides an Empty rectangle. X and Y are positive-infinity and Width and Height are negative infinity. This is the only situation where Width or Height can be negative.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Height
member.summary: Height - The Height component of the JetSize. This cannot be set to negative, and will only be negative if this is the empty rectangle, in which case it will be negative infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.IsEmpty
member.summary: IsEmpty - this returns true if this rect is the Empty rectangle. Note: If width or height are 0 this Rectangle still contains a 0 or 1 dimensional set of points, so this method should not be used to check for 0 area.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Left
member.summary: Left Property - This is a read-only alias for X If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Location
member.summary: Location - The JetPoint representing the origin of the Rectangle

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Right
member.summary: Right Property - This is a read-only alias for X + Width If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Size
member.summary: JetSize - The JetSize representing the area of the Rectangle

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Top
member.summary: Top Property - This is a read-only alias for Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.TopLeft
member.summary: TopLeft Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPoint which is at X, Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity, positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.TopRight
member.summary: TopRight Property - This is a read-only alias for the JetPoint which is at X + Width, Y If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be negative infinity, positive infinity.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Width
member.summary: Width - The Width component of the JetSize. This cannot be set to negative, and will only be negative if this is the empty rectangle, in which case it will be negative infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.X
member.summary: X - The X coordinate of the Location. If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect.Y
member.summary: Y - The Y coordinate of the Location If this is the empty rectangle, the value will be positive infinity. If this rect is Empty, setting this property is illegal.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.WinApiInterop
member.summary: Coordinates interop with WinAPI. This is build-safe because even though it's not applicable to all OSes, all of the types here are our own and are fully functional (as data types) on any OS.

member.name: T:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages
member.summary: Represents a set of device-dependent raster images. This is supposed to be the same image but for different resolutions (possibly, with different detail level).

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages.Images
member.summary: The images, sorted by resolution, ascending. We expect to have PNG-encoded raster images here.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages.FindNearest(JetBrains.Util.Interop.DpiResolution)
member.summary: Looks up an image with the closest resoluion.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages.FromTwoResx(System.IO.UnmanagedMemoryStream,System.IO.UnmanagedMemoryStream)
member.summary: When you have an image for normal resolution and for double resolution in ResX resources of type declaration-side, which makes in code.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages.FromTwoStreams(JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.ImmutableByteStream,JetBrains.Util.dataStructures.ImmutableByteStream)
member.summary: When you have an image for normal resolution and for double resolution in immutable streams.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Media.Imaging.RasterDeviceImages.TryGetExact(JetBrains.Util.Interop.DpiResolution)
member.summary: Looks up an image from the list for this exact resolution. NULL if none. Does not look up nearest or resample.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.AvalonBasedTiGeometryHelpers.WriteTiSegment_AvalonEngineConversion(JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgGrammar.PD.TiSegmentWriter,JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgGrammar.PD.SA)
member.summary: This method uses the Avalon engine to convert arc segments into bézier segments, which it does when it has to apply transforms to the points. This uses the undefined behavior and is not very cross-platform.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.ArcPathToCenterCoordinates(JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.ArcInPathCoordinates,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts the arc representation from a path arc into the ellipse-centric arc. Based on the SVG 1.1 (Second Edition) standard — Appendix F: Implementation Requirements — F.6 Elliptical arc implementation notes — F.6.5 Conversion from endpoint to center parameterization, https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/implnote.html#ArcConversionEndpointToCenter . Does NOT handle the out-of-range cases correctly, as customary for SVG processing.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.ArcToBézierCurves(JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.ArcInCenterCoordinates)
member.summary: Approximates an arc with a number of curves, small enough for the approximation to be decent. See for details. The returned curves are contiguous, i.e. the next start point is the prev end point, and also smooth.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.BézierTryDecreaseDegreeCubicToQuadratic(JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.BézierCubicCurve)
member.summary: If a cubic curve were made by elevating degree of a quadratic (or just happens to match), converts it back. Otherwise, a NULL.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.RoundRectToBézierCurvesForCorners(JetBrains.Util.Media.JetRect,JetBrains.Util.Media.JetSize)
member.summary: Makes Bézier curves for the corners of a rectangle with rounded corners. They're ordered to go one after another, so just connect with straight lines to get a rounded rect path.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.SmallArcToBézierCurve(JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.GeometryHelpers.ArcInCenterCoordinates)
member.summary: Converts an arc to a Bézier curve, only if it's small enough to be suitably represented by a curve (here this means a quarter circle at most). The curve is chosen to match the coordinates in the starting and ending points of the arc, their first derivative, and their second derivative. Based on the https://www.spaceroots.org/documents/ellipse/elliptical-arc.pdf article.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.id
member.summary: Resources, like gradients: gets listed in resource map under this ID. Other elements, like graphics or groups: potentially allows tricks with them, but useless for our needs, just ignore; Sketch would plant them all around.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.enable_background
member.summary: Deprecated. Can appear on any element, but has effect only on svg and g as of which we are interested in. On shapes, should have no effect, but we'd sometimes see it on AI exports. The docs are complicated, probably should affect some advanced compositing, like access to intermediate render results from the elements renderers.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.href
member.summary: This is actually an attribute in the namespace, , but we must be listing it together with other attributes as well.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.clip_rule
member.summary: Adobe Illustrator tends to set this (illegaly) on shapes sometimes, together with a pretty legal . We'll just let it be, but ignore the value.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.data_name
member.summary: Encountered in XD exports, randomly added to seemingly anything (especially root and graphics).

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.fill_opacity
member.summary: Some AI exports set this instead of opacity, maybe based on how the fill were defined.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.stroke
member.summary: We do not support stroke intentionally, by design all stroke-like painting should be done with paths. The original motivation was that there're many peculiarities around painting strokes, caps, miters and all, even within renderers of the same format (say, SVG), and we're trying to render even across formats, into WPF. So the safe version is to render with paths, which produce a fully defined outline, which is pretty compatible across all formats. We still support specifying some stroke properties because they'd be encountered in Sketch exports of certain formats/methods though, but assert they're trivial.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgFile.Attribute.isolation
member.summary: This is actually CSS not SVG, but might be encountered in SVG styles. This affects stacking contexts (like, manual z-ordering), which isn't very applicable to us, and prevents blending (multiply, etc) if it's nonstandard, which we do not support anyway. So we can safely ignore “auto” or “isolate” or whatever values here, I believe they cannot affect anything much.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgGrammar.SvgPathCommandsApplyImplicitConversions(Sprache.IResult{System.Collections.Generic.ICollection{JetBrains.Util.Icons.Emitters.SvgGrammar.PD.S}})
member.summary: SVG Path commands have certain implicit conventions which change the command to another one based on its context. 1) A set of MoveTo commands at the beginning of a figure becomes a set of (one MoveTo command plus LineTo commands). 2) A leading MoveTo-Relative in the path is changed to Absolute, but its following MoveTo-autochanged-into-LineTo remain Relative (that's why it's allowed to write it relative).

summary.para: General conversions for the format to and from the popular formats.

Special cases are handled by other classes, like export to C# (ThemedIconsCsEmitter) or import from SVG (SvgThemedIconsTransferFormatParser), as it's a complicated lossy import process). The conversions presented here are usually simple and lossless — provided that Avalon vector images comply with what's allowed for a TiIcon.

summary.para: Represents a radial gradient brush, in element-relative coordinates, where (0,0) is the left-top point of the bounding box, and (1,1) is the bottom right.

A radial gradient has a starting point (0% gradient stop) from which it goes to the ending ellipse (100% gradient stop). It is not sufficient to specify the ellipse because it might also be skewed and rotated, which can't be expressed with just the ellipse axes.

So we would assume the initial ellipse as a circle at (0,0) with radius 1, onto which a transform is applied to achieve the resulting ellipse. The starting point is expressed in the coordinate space in which the ellipse is a unit circle, i.e. the ellipse transform also applies to the starting point.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Icons.TiRadialGradientBrush.Transform
member.summary: The transform which would make the (0,0),1 circle the desired end-ellipse in the element-bounding-box-relative coordinates.

summary.para: Enforces waiting for all pending messages to be processed before closing the channel — you must be sure that the writer has disconnected in such case, otherwise you might be waiting indefinitely.

Terminating the reader lifetime aborts reading and cancels remaining messages in case you want to break the channel no matter what happens to the other end. If you terminate the other end and want to make sure that all pending messages are read, call this method before proceeding with lifetime termination.

member.summary: Turns item into bytes for sending. This might happen on the sender thread, not when the item is request for sending. That's why you write items in the API, not bytes, and we need a separate functor for turning items into bytes.
member.param: The item to serialize.

In: the buffer for writing, content undefined. If too small, allocate a new one. Out: the buffer stuff has been actually written into, might be the input one. This buffer would be reused when returned, do not treat it as owned or readonly.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.ParallelAttemptsLimit
member.summary: An async semaphore to prevent opening too many objects at the same time. Which is not supposed to be a problem, they have their internal limit and should await, but it's been observed that something breaks under intensive use and all further download attemps are blocked.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.ServicePointConnectionLimit
member.summary: Limits the number of dloads from the same server. Applied when we prepare a specific request. The default limit is 2 in .NET since ages. For current massive workloads this is suboptimal, and e.g. Nuget 5 would also increase this to be 64. With poor connections, TCP/IP overhead limits bandwidth dramatically on ack/resend, so running multiple downloads at the same time increases utilization on bad connections as well. Modern servers wouldn't care much I believe.

MUST support seeking for the case if the download interrupts, has to be restarted, and resuming from the same spot is not possible (if resumes are not prohibited).
MUST be at position zero, otherwise the existing bytes are assumed to be partially downloaded content to be resumed (if resumes are not prohibited).

member.summary: Optional. If is given, specifies custom content type for it.

summary.para: Advanced. Overrides various timeouts starting with TimeoutAtomic… in .

Those timeouts prevent from unexpected freezes in server operations and shan't be hit with normal servers. However, some servers might be implementing REST-like blocking APIs for lengthy operations, so that opening a request might await on queue for access to server resources, and getting the response might await on the operation itself, each of these possibly lasting for tens of minutes. This control allows to lift the limitations, all at once. Individual tweaks might be exposed as well, but at this moment this is not needed.
or means no timeout. A NULL value means the operation-specific timeout from .
The timeout for each of the download operations (attemps). Gets passed to the HTTP request.
or means no timeout. A NULL value means .

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.SendReceiveBufferCbSize
member.summary: Size of the chunks we are reading from the receiving stream. Making them too small might be suboptimal with larger payloads. Making them too large has two problems: (a) LOH hits, (b) progress is only reported in between chunks, so with a very large buffer we might not be getting progress reports.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.TimeoutAtomicOnErrorMessageResponse
member.summary: When Web server reports a failure, wait at most this time for the full response error message.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.TimeoutAtomicOpenRequestStream
member.summary: Timeout on opening the request stream for uploading the request payload (if present), on each attempt. NOTE this does not include the time for uploading the payload itself, just opening the stream.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.TimeoutAtomicOpenResponse
member.summary: Timeout on getting the response object. NOTE this does not include actually downloading any bytes, just the initial opening of the response.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.TimeoutAtomicSingleBufferLocalReadWrite
member.summary: Sanity time limit on writing to the local output stream, or reading from the local stream with content for uploading, if async API is used (unless it's a well-known mem stream).

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Networking.HttpDownload.Flags.Defaults.TimeoutAtomicSingleBufferRemoteReadWrite
member.summary: Timeout on one async stream operation with one buffer of size over the remote stream (upload for sending request payload, download when downloading the response body). This does not cover the error text, see instead. NOTE this is not timing out the whole download/upload operation, just one chunk. We assume that if bytes are coming TOO slowly, or got stuck and not coming at all without breaking the connection (happens on mobile internet), we should rather drop this attempt and re-initiate, since we're good at retrying.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.NumberUtilParsing.TryParseFloatingPoint(System.Byte*,System.UInt32,System.Double*)
member.summary: Duplicates the code in , as borrowed from CoreCLR, with the following differences: (1) Parses only for AllowLeadingSign+AllowExponent+AllowDecimalPoint. No currency, no thousands. (2) Parses only for the Invariant Culture, only dots for decimal points. (3) Operates on the memory pointer rather than a string managed object. This is the key point. (4) Does not need a terminating zero at the end of the string. This allows to parse a part of the input stream. (5) The input is in bytes, and is assumed to be in a multibyte encoding such as ASCII or ANSI or UTF-8 — for normal doubles, that's no difference, with the exception of the “∞” char which might occur in the in R mode, which is expected to be expressed as three UTF-8 bytes. Any unexpected byte value aborts parsing.

member.summary: Duplicates the code in , as borrowed from CoreCLR, with the following differences: (1) Parses only for AllowLeadingSign+AllowExponent+AllowDecimalPoint. No currency, no thousands. (2) Parses only for the Invariant Culture, only dots for decimal points. (3) Operates on the memory pointer rather than a string managed object. This is the key point. (4) Does not need a terminating zero at the end of the string. This allows to parse a part of the input stream.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Processes.DotNetGlobalToolsRunnerHelpers.RunCltWithCustomRuntimeConfig(JetBrains.Util.FileSystemPath,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: If the clt was run on windows on NETCore.App (it is the case if cross platform tool it started as dotnet global tool) this method helps to run the clt using proper runtimeconfig with specified suffix So we will have the first process (which runs on NETCore.App as runner and calls this method) and the second (which runs on proper runtimeConfig and do the job) Features: 1. The second process can properly work with stdin/out/err 2. Returned exit code will be propagated from second process to the first 3. The Ctrl-C, Ctrl-Break signals won't affect the first application (it still will be waiting for the second application exit) 4. If the first process is terminated the second is also will be terminated (jobs are used as in InvokeChildProcess)
member.param: Path to the clt assembly
The suffix to the runtime config. The path to config file will be without extension + .runtimeconfig + + .json>
member.returns: Propagated exit code
member.exception: Throws exception in case it is not possible to run second application

member.summary: Initiates the process graceful shutdown by closing its main window. Optionally, kills the process abruptly if the shutdown fails to complete as the timeout expires.

Behavior flags.
The timeout to wait for the process to shutdown gracefully (before exiting or killing the process). Ignored in some combinations.
Optional logger

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.ProcessUtil.ShutdownFlags.KillAfterTimeout

member.name: P:JetBrains.Util.RichText.JetFont.EmSizeInDip
member.summary: This is the em-size of the font, aka character size, or character cell height minus internal leading. The units are device-independent pixels (96 DPI pixels, Avalon pixels, logical pixels). This isn't in points, which are 72 DPI pixels. The value is directly usable for Avalon font sizes. For WinForms, it must be scaled to the DPI, and units must be set to pixels. Do not use resolution-independent units such as points for WinForms, because often the rendering engine does not know the correct DPI value at render time, better use our live DPI routines and get the physical pixels ourselves.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Serialization.CsexpReader.ReportDelayedError(System.Exception)
member.summary: If an error happens on a closing bracket of a using construct, this is often due to an exception somewhere inside the bracket (which unbalances the rest of the reading within the bracket). Throwing from the closing bracket is undesired because if there is an exception being propagated, said exception (which explains everything) will be totally lost and replaced with a useless exception about unbalancing the reader. Throw out on the next regular read operation (skips are not considered as they happen on bracked closings).

summary.para: Represents a file item which takes part in the build or other similar operations. It has a name (possibly, with partial folder path), but is not bound to any specific location on disk; it has a body, which is an immutable stream of bytes.

remarks.para: Disconnecting file items from specific disk paths makes operations more reliable. Firstly, getting a file item means a correct dependency on its producer, while reading a disk path might be based on well-known paths or guesswork, and miss the actual dependency on the producer. Secondly, passing around file items allows running operations in parallel without aliasing over the same disk locations. All this might be achieved on disk paths as well, but has rather weak guarantees to always hold in large systems with long history.

summary.para: The byte content of the file. This stream is frozen, initially positioned at the beginning, and does not share its current position with other callers.

member.remarks: A shallow clone is created for each caller. This means that (a) callers don't affect each other's stream positions, (b) there is a slight memory penalty for creating a small wrapper object on each call, and (c) the full contents of the underlying buffers are not cloned but reused immutably.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Storage.ImmutableFileItemEx.RealizeOnDisk(JetBrains.Util.Storage.ImmutableFileItem,JetBrains.Lifetimes.Lifetime,JetBrains.Util.IWorkingDirectory)
member.summary: Temporarily realizes the file item as a physical disk file.

summary.para: Ideally, file items should be non-lifetimed and GC controlled. In reality, to optimize memory use, sometimes the immutable byte streams inside the file items might have limited lifetime. To make it worse, file items might derive these streams from some other storage different from the immediate originator of the file, and its lifetime might be even shorter. An example is when the creator of the file item artifact is deserializing from some interprocess transport stream, the stream might be short-lived.
This method tries to ensure that the memory owned by this file item has no end of life. Returns a new instance only if a change were made.

summary.para: Gets the package parts as file items. No filtering applied. Parts are sorted by their part paths as s.
For most practical needs, you'd need a filtered set with effective paths, for which look for .
Notes on performance.
In case of a nugettable, parts are stored as file items and this provides direct access.
In case of a nupkg, these are lazy promises which would decompress file content on-demand, which is a costly operation for larger items.
In case of a nupkg + scattered package on disk, larger items would be served from uncompressed disk copies, if available, which should be not as costly.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.IJetNugetPackage.FilterPackageParts(JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.JetNugetFilterFlags,JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.JetNugetTargetFramework)
member.summary: Gets the parts of the Nuget package (this skips the nuspec, and of course skips technical OPC package ZIP entires which are not parts).
member.param: Flags to skip certain items, for speed.

param.name: targetfx
param.para: Allows to limit the extracted content items by a specific Target Framework.
Not filtering (not ): gets the union of all the content items for any frameworks; might yield items with the same (but different of course). This is the legacy behavior.
Filtering ():
• Illegal if not .
• Returns content items for this specific framework only.

• If limiting for the specific framework yields an empty list, falls back to the original behavior as if this were NULL. This is a compatibility fix to make sure that we're still able to support projects targeting the non-solution-standard fx version and their custom nuget references.
The commonly-used value would be .

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.JetNugetFilterFlags.ContentPreferRuntimesFolder
member.summary: Modifier for mode. Historically, we've been taking the (lib) folder from non-ours packages. With newer nugets and multiple supported target frameworks, it is sometimes needed to take the specifically tailored assemblies from the (runtime) folder when running on a specific target system. Still falls back to lib folder if no refs.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.JetNugetFilterFlags.ContentIncludeRuntimesFolder
member.summary: Modifier for mode. Historically, we've been taking the (lib) folder from non-ours packages. With newer nugets and multiple supported target frameworks, it is sometimes needed to take the specifically tailored assemblies from the (runtime) folder when running on a specific target system, but they should be used together with regular libs, so this reads from both content and runtime folders.

member.name: M:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.JetNuGetSettingsV2.LoadDefaultSettings(NuGet.IFileSystem,System.String)
member.summary: Loads user settings from the NuGet configuration files. The method walks the directory tree in up to its root, and reads each NuGet.config file it finds in the directories. It then reads the user specific settings, which is file in if is not null, If is null, the user specific settings file is %AppData%\NuGet\NuGet.config. After that, the machine wide settings files are added.
member.remarks:
For example, if is c:\dir1\dir2, is "userConfig.file", the files loaded are (in the order that they are loaded): c:\dir1\dir2
uget.config c:\dir1
uget.config c:
uget.config c:\dir1\dir2\userConfig.file machine wide settings (e.g. c:\programdata\NuGet\Config\*.config)
member.param: The file system to walk to find configuration files.
The user specified configuration file.
member.returns: The settings object loaded.

After that, the machine wide settings files are added.
member.remarks:

member.param: The root directory.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.LocalPackagesMeta.PackageRecord.TimeoutOnNugetMetaLock
member.summary: The timeout to wait for a lock when trying to open metadata on a nuget entry in the Central Cache or a Local Restore folder. This might mean that another thread/process is also performing an operation on the same package location. The supposedly most lengthy operation is package download, which also locks the folder (why not? you cannot local restore a package before you download it. and you do not want to run simultaneous downloads). We got large packages and possibly slow connections. Do not limit the process.

member.name: F:JetBrains.Util.Storage.Packages.LocalPackagesMeta.PackageRecord.PackageVersionString
